conclusion: Wave 1 originates at x = -0.2 m and propagates toward positive x-direction with speed v1 = 0.4 m/s.
Wave 2 originates at x = 1.2 m and propagates toward negative x-direction with speed v2 = 0.4 m/s.
The two waves will meet at some point along the x-axis.
Define the meeting point as x_meet where the positions of the two wave fronts coincide at time t_meet.
The position of the left wave front at time t is x_left(t) = -0.2 + v1 t.
The position of the right wave front at time t is x_right(t) = 1.2 - v2 t.
At the meeting point, x_left(t_meet) = x_right(t_meet).
Substitute the equations for x_left(t) and x_right(t) into the equality: -0.2 + v1 t_meet = 1.2 - v2 t_meet.
Substitute v1 = v2 = 0.4 m/s: -0.2 + 0.4 t_meet = 1.2 - 0.4 t_meet.
Calculate the position of the meeting point x_meet: x_meet = x_left(t_meet) = -0.2 + 0.4 * 1.75 = 0.5 m.
Both calculations confirm that the waves meet at x = 0.5 m, which is the equilibrium position of particle M.
The two waves meet at t_meet = 1.75 s.
